[API] Fixed the "greedy" regex in the `Utils.__rescue_from_not_found` method

The previous implementation of the `Utils.__rescue_from_not_found` method matched the exception
method on a pattern including `404`, which has led to incorrectly capturing eg. the
`Elasticsearch::Transport::Transport::Errors::Conflict` exception, when the document
version or ID contained the `404` string.

This patch narrows the regex pattern to only look for the "Not Found" string, in order
with the original motivation to enable this functionality also in custom clients,
not based on the `elasticsearch-transport` Rubygem.

It also fixes the `rescue` clause itself, to only catch exceptions descending from
`StandardError`, not `Exception`.

Tests have been updated accordingly.

[CLIENT] Don't block waiting for body on HEAD requests

Since "Add correct Content-Length on HEAD requests"
(elastic/elasticsearch#21123), Elasticsearch correctly returns a non
zero Content-Length header. Unfortunately that uncovered a bug in the
Curb transport driver.

HEAD responses are special, they return a non zero Content-Length header
but send no body at all. libcurl by default expects to read
`Content-Length` bytes which are never sent. This causes libcurl to
block until the timeout is reached.

Since we use the low-level `http()` curb interface we have to explicitly
set `CURLOPT_NOBODY` before the request.

Closes #433

[CLIENT] Prevent losing of protocol and credentials after connection reloading

Before this patch, people were struggling with using HTTPS and authentication together
with connection reloading ("sniffing"), because it wasn't evident that cluster-wide
information (such as credentials) have to be passed to the client initializer (see a289f4d).

This patch introduces a new key for the client initializer, `http`, to store such information,
and updates the code in `__extract_hosts` to transfer the information from the host configuration
into this Hash. Therefore, it's now possible to do:

    Elasticsearch::Transport::Client.new \
      host: { host: '127.0.0.1', port: 8080 },
      http: { scheme: 'https', user: 'username', password: 'password' };

or even:

    Elasticsearch::Transport::Client.new url: 'https://username:password@127.0.0.1:8080'

and this configuration won't be lost after reloading connections, because it's merged
back into the host info during `__build_connections`.

NOTE:

It's not possible without some manual intervention to eg. use Nginx
as a reverse proxy for Elasticsearch and call `reload_connections!`, because
the HTTP port will be fetched from "Nodes Info", and won't match the port
of the proxy.

The practical solution for this would be to implement a custom `Sniffer`
class, which would transform the information returned from "Nodes Info"
and update the port (and possibly other information) accordingly.

[CLIENT] Added auto-detection for Faraday adapter from loaded Rubygems

Given the importance of using persistent HTTP connections to Elasticsearch,
the default client configuration has a fairly poor performance.

Since Faraday, the "abstract" HTTP library used as the default transport implementation
comes with adapters for many high-performance libraries (eg. Patron or Typhoeus),
we should detect when a library like this is loaded, and use it as the HTTP "driver"
(adapter) automatically.

With this change, we're no longer forcing users to "configure" their client:
they simply `require` a high-performance HTTP library and it is used automatically.

Example (adapted from README):

    require 'patron'

    client = Elasticsearch::Client.new

    client.transport.connections.first.connection.builder.handlers
    # => [Faraday::Adapter::Patron]

    10.times do
      client.nodes.stats(metric: 'http')['nodes'].values.each do |n|
        puts "#{n['name']} : #{n['http']['total_opened']}"
      end
    end

    # => Stiletoo : 24
    # => Stiletoo : 24
    # => Stiletoo : 24
    # => ...

Of course, users can set a specific adapter when creating the client:

    client = Elasticsearch::Client.new adapter: :net_http_persistent

    client.transport.connections.first.connection.builder.handlers
    # => [Faraday::Adapter::NetHttpPersistent]

See the list of supported adapters for Faraday:

<https://github.com/lostisland/faraday/tree/master/lib/faraday/adapter>

Benchmarks show that Patron (a `libcurl` based client) performs quite exceptionally:

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Context: Net:HTTP should get the cluster info (5000x)
mean: 3.61ms | avg: 7.95ms | max: 1318.01ms
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Context: Patron should get the cluster info (5000x)
mean: 2.43ms | avg: 2.78ms | max: 48.08ms
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Context: Typhoeus should get the cluster info (5000x)
mean: 4.31ms | avg: 4.71ms | max: 50.78ms
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

(Full benchmark/profile included in <https://github.com/elasticsearch/elasticsearch-ruby/blob/master/elasticsearch-transport/test/profile/client_benchmark_test.rb>)

[CLIENT] Correctly return Hashes from `perfom_request` with the Curb transport

Because of the change introduced in elasticsearch/elasticsearch-ruby#80c48dd,
responses from the Curb transport were not correctly deserialized into Hash from JSON string.

That's because we actually haven't returned any response headers in the `Curb#perform_request` method.

Since Curb doesn't return any response headers as a Hash (see related), we simply check for:

    header_str =~ /\/json/

in `Curb#perform_request`.

This seems to have noticeable impact on the raw performance, adding ~ 10ms to _mean_ times
when running the client benchmark test. On the other hand, previously we did check body
whether it "looks like a JSON", which definitely has been influencing the end times,
so hopefully it balances out.

Once Curb adds response headers as a Hash, the code should change appropriately.

[API] Changed, that API parameters are not only whitelisted, but verified

Previously, valid parameters for each API were extracted from the arguments Hash,
and the rest was silently discarded.

This could lead to hard to debug behaviour or hideous bugs due to typos. To prevent this,
the arguments Hash is compared to a list of valid keys. When an invalid key is being
passed to an API, `ArgumentError` exception is raised.

For example:

    client.search :search_type => 'count', :qwertypoiuy => 'asdflkjhg'
    # => ArgumentError: URL parameter 'qwertypoiuy' is not supported

Furthermore, consistency with the Python and PHP clients in this regard is achieved.

Changed the URL-escape ("urlencode") behaviour in the `Utils` module

Previously, the `Elasticsearch::API::Utils.__escape` method was using `URI.encode`,
which escaped only characters, which shouldn't appear in URLs "naked".

This was inconsistent with other clients, and also made it cumbersome when trying
to eg. index a document with `type: "mynamespace/model" -- as is common in Rails applications.

With this change, `__escape` uses `CGI.escape` -- or `EscapeUtils.escape_url` when available --
to perform a *full* URL-encoding of the passed in argument.

`__pathify` has been changed to not perform any escaping, and `__listify` was changed
to escape all list items separately.

Related: #7

Changed URL extraction in Elasticsearch::Client to allow more flexibility

Previously, it wasn't possible to fully configure the Elasticsearch endpoint URL, eg. to allow `https` protocol,
to pass HTTP Basic Auth credentials, or to configure a URL prexic without implementing a custom transport.

Now, any URL is handled automatically (using `URI.parse`):

    Elasticsearch::Client.new url: 'https://myserver:4430/search'

Code, tests and documentation have been updated accordingly.

[API] Added a source code generator using the JSON API specs

The generator is based on [Thor](https://github.com/wycats/thor),
a library/framework for command line applications.

The generator will read the JSON API spec file(s), and generate
the Ruby source code (one file per API endpoint) with correct
module namespace, method names, and RDoc documentation.

It will generate a test file for each API endpoint as well.

Currently it only generates Ruby source, but can easily be
extended and adapted to generate source code for other
programming languages.

Usage example:

    $ time thor api:generate ../../api-spec/*.json --force --verbose

hitting the same nodes at once, expose a setting to randomize the
host list for each client:

    Elasticsearch::Client::Client.new %w| localhost:9250 foobar1 |, randomize_hosts: true

The hosts array will be refreshed on initialization and sniffing then.

[CLIENT] Added the "dead pool" feature

The <Connection> object tracks it state (`dead -- alive -- healthy`),
as well as number of times it has failed.

Depending on the resurrect timeout and the number of failures, it can be resurrected,
ie. returned into the alive collection -- see Connection#resurrect!

The <Collection> object now returns only "alive" connections.

The <Transport> object now periodically performs connection resurrection in `get_connection`,
and marks connections as dead / healthy based on whether a request succeeded or failed.

If there's no alive connection, a dead connection with least errors is "forcibly resurrected"
in Collection#get_connection.
